awd_titl_txt: NSF Student Travel Grant for IEEE SmartCloud 2017
awd_abstract_narration:
This project proposes funding for SmartCloud 2017 (The 2nd IEEE International Conference on SmartCloud 2017, http://smartcloud2017.smart-com.org) to support undergraduate/graduate students, especially under-represented students, who are interested in cloud computing research and pursuing cloud-related research work.  Student presenters/attendees learn a great deal by participating in this type of academic event. SmartCoud 2017 has multiple parallel sessions with different foci where professional presentations on recent research will be presented by senior researchers.

There is a serious plan to recruit minority students and underrepresented groups, engage them in the activities provided by the conference, such as panels and workshops, and give them priority to participate when opportunities are limited.  The conference provides a valuable forum for introducing new techniques, sharing new tools, and reviewing upcoming publications to future potential researchers, allowing for opportunities to advance their education and explore career development by building professional and academic social networks.

Project Summary:

 

In 2018, the 3rd IEEE International Conference on Smart Cloud (SmartCloud 2018), had been held from September 21st to Septermber 23rd, at Columbia University in New York city. We supported anther 9 students to assist them in participating in this important academic event. Each student had been awarded $900 in average. The awarded students had a chance to communicate with many active and distinguishing scholars who are working in the field of cloud computing. Taking part in the forum had been an excellent experience for all awarded students. However, the fund of $8198 is still in the transfer status. The PI had transferred from Columbia University to Harrisburg University in Fall 2018. But the transfer process is still not finished.

In 2017, there are total 9 students who had been granted by this fund. These 9 students attended the 2nd IEEE International Conference on Smart Cloud 2017 (SmartCloud 2017) in New York during the period of November 3rd – 5th. All students were asked to submit a report after the conference. According to their responses, all awarded students felt that they had a meaningful and helpful journey due to the fund support. The acquisition from attending the conference is remarkably significant for their research work. For example, Abdulhamid Adebowal Adebayo, one of awarded students, mentioned that he “had the opportunity of meeting a number of revered researchers in my field who were more than happy to share their thoughts and also introduce me to a number of research paths” in his report. 

 

 

Project outcomes:

 

-Intellectual merit:

 

First, student presenters or attendees had learned and gained a lot in these academic events at their early academic career stage. It is always important for young students to keep it in mind that they need to have something presentable even though some ideas are fundamental, such as a literature review, the theoretical framework, or some hypotheses. Attending an international conference is a good start for training early in their early career.

Second, funding supported students got to know other young or senior scholars, and will be known in academic circles of cloud computing when attending SmartCloud 2017 and 2018. For example, SmartCloud 2017 and 2018 had host a panel by inviting a few reputable scholars specialized in cloud computing, which provides students with a great opportunity to ask questions or have conversation with experts. The experience of attending our panel is beneficial for students to attend other panels or networks.

Third, SmartCoud 2017 and 2018 had multiple parallel sessions with different focuses. Each session consists of four or five professional presentations regarding the recent research achievements, mostly given by senior researchers. Students learned from these presentations and improve their own skills and knowledge in cloud computing. It is also valuable for students to exchange ideas during or even after the presentations, since joining the networks in cloud computing is important. Students also had a chance to be invited to join collective research projects.

Finally, building up academic networks is a fundamental for young scholars to obtaining a position in academia. These benefits particularly support efforts to financial support young students to join the event.

 

-Broader of impacts:

 

First, this project reach out to minority students and underrepresented groups through the proposed activities, and give them priority to participate when opportunities are limited. We also encourage minority students and females to participate in the student workshop and research activities in the project. We had supported 3 female and minority students to attend the 2017 event and 2 in 2018 event.

Second, our well designed event program is a great examination of testing new technologies, reviewing upcoming publications, or sharing new tools in an open forum, which is a valuable attempt of introducing new techniques to future potential researchers or investors. Students had a chance to build up their knowledge structure by attending different presentation sessions and listening to keynotes’ lectures.

Third, the proposed activities provide community college students with opportunities to advance their education and explore careers via building up professional or academic social networks.

Fourth, the project provides community college faculty with resources and supports towards establishing their research program environment including attracting students, developing faculty expertise, and improving curriculum. Our proposed activities had a significant impact on both education and research in the cloud computing field for all participating colleges and enabled them to produce more and better prepared smart cloud professionals to meet the increasing demands of both the public and private sectors.

Modified by: Meikang Qiu
